page.title: 12ASHDOWN FOREST FOR STUDY
page.content: Students of all ages from school chil- dren to serious archeologists come to learn about the Forest. On private land in the North West corner of our block there were recently important excavations revealing the site of an Iron Age Fort and a Roman Villa. Afterwards the top-soil was replaced until further work could be done. The London-Lewes Roman Road ran close to the present B2026 and a small grass- covered raised section of it has now been marked and described on a plaque. There have been excavations showing that iron was produced here from Roman times until the 17th century. It is hard to imagine the Forest as an industrial region but the use of wood for charcoal is the reason for its present relatively treeless condition. An orientation table was erected to commemorate the Silver Jubilee in 1977
